user.biography: What’s it take to create a @natgeo photograph?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 20, 2021. May be an image of fire and nature.

node.text:
Photos and video by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom /In La Palma Island (Canary Islands) after a week with more than 20 thousand low intensity earthquakes finally the Cumbre Vieja (Old Summit) volcano erupted on Sunday. There are currently 5,000 displaced people on the island and hundreds of homes affected.

#CanaryIslands #lapalma #Spain

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 18, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and monument.

node.text: Photos of @stephenwilkes / Viewed from 45 feet above The National Mall seen working on my latest Day to Night, the installation, In America: Remember, is a memorial of historic scale during a time when many of us have not been able to mourn the tragic losses due to COVID. It serves as a harrowing reminder of the sheer scale of devastation and loss wrought by more than 670,000 lives lost to this pandemic. Each life, commemorated by a small white flag, spread over acres on National Park land, sprawling beneath an enduring American monument. The artist @suzannefirstenberg created this extraordinary and powerful exhibit where she  invites visitors to personalize the flags by writing the names of loved ones lost to the pandemic. Photo by @lennychristopher @johnboalphotography

Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of monument and nature.

node.text: Photos by @waynelawrence / Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg collaborated with Ruppert Landscape to install an artwork composed of 143 sections of white flags and 3.8 miles of walking paths at the foot of the Washington Monument. White benches are placed throughout to allow visitors to sit in quiet reflection. Suzanne chose white flags to represent the lives lost because they are a sign of purity and of the spirit—and to make it easier for people to personalize them. For those that cannot make it to Washington, D.C., requests for messages can be made online and the flag will be available to view on a digital map of the installation. @inamericaflags

node.text:
Timelapse by @frostjeff / Although you cannot see the massive trees themselves, this sunset timelapse is pointed straight at several groves of giant sequoias, the largest trees on Earth. Access to these groves has been exceedingly difficult, but it is of profound importance that these events be shown. The loss of giant sequoia trees is a true tragedy for all inhabitants of Earth. 

50 miles apart the #WindyFire and the #KNPcomplex fires threaten multiple groves of endangered giant sequoia trees. @stuartpalley and I managed to make it to a grove yesterday, but were forced to turn around immediately due to the Windy Fire making a rapid uphill run towards our position on a dusty mountain road where firefighters worked overtime to create a fire break and protect the groves. 

Fewer than 80,000 giant sequoias remain. It is estimated that 10-14% of the population perished in the 2020 #CastleFire alone.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, flower and outdoors.

node.text: Photos and videos of @waynelawrence / I am here at the National Mall of Washington D.C on assignment for @natgeo covering the art installation of over 670,000 flags in memory of those who have passed away from the COVID-19 virus. The art installation is thanks to the artist, Suzanne Firstenberg (@suzannefirstenberg) and Rupert landscaping. While I am here, I will be interacting with the many volunteers, the artist herself, and those who come to remember their loved ones who have passed. @inamericaflags / Photos and videos by @mayanmvalentine @julianthomas_ and @viewsby.chris

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of standing, outdoors and monument.
Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in North Carolina. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text: Photo by @macstonephoto / The ancient bald cypress along the Black River in North Carolina comprise the oldest swamp in the world. Protected by The Nature Conservancy (@tnc_nc), this old growth forest is one of the few remaining virgin swamps left in the United States. With the record age of 2,624 years, these sentinel trees have witnessed millennia of storms, hurricanes, droughts, fires, sunrises and moon sets. But on September 15, 2021 at precisely 8:06pm, the sky illuminated with a new and historic feature. SpaceX’s Inspiration4 flight ushered in a new era becoming the first all-civilian crew to reach orbit. The launch was visible in North Carolina for only 120 seconds. While deep in the swamp, I noticed something strange streaking behind the canopy. Alarmed, I yelled in confusion to my assistant, Zach, thinking it was a comet or a rocket. I quickly recomposed my camera and captured the SpaceX rocket heading northeast across the heavens. It was incredible to witness and what also struck me was the duality of the moment—new technology soaring over ancient trees. For more photos of swamps and wetlands, follow @macstonephoto

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, brick wall and outdoors.

node.text:
Photos and video by @davillasana / Alexa Smith, a transgender migrant from Honduras, spends most of her days inside as she doesn’t always feel safe in her new neighborhood of Memphis, Tennessee, due to violence and insecurity. Her and her boyfriend, also a migrant from Honduras, have been fighting more often, she says, causing a great strain on their relationship. 

Wanting a break from tensions at home, Alexa decided to take a trip to Texas where her sister also recently migrated to from Honduras. Writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) recently visited Alexa for @natgeo about her life now in the United States after crossing into the country earlier this year. 

As I’ve been following Alexa since 2018, she’s very familiar with my work as a photojournalist and loves looking at pictures—she’s even helped me select photos and I love hearing her feedback. This gallery includes a moment of Alexa looking at images I made on this most recent trip. 

Keep an eye out for our upcoming @natgeo story about Alexa and Kataleya, two trans migrants from Honduras who have overcome incredible odds while still facing challenges in the United States.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.
Photo by Nat Geo in the Field in Sequoia National Park. May be an image of fire and outdoors.

node.text:
Photo by @stuartpalley / The #KNPComplex burns in Sequoia National Park Wednesday evening September 15th, 2021. The fire is comprised of the Paradise and Colony Fires, both lightning ignited blazes that started last week. The fire was close to the Giants Grove of Giant Sequoias in the park, as crews worked to protect infrastructure and the trees in advance of the fire. The National Park Service has conducted numerous prescribed burns over the years in Giant Sequoia Groves, and fire crews are optimistic that this previous managed “good fire” will allow a healthy burn to move through the forest around some famous trees like the General Sherman and others, if or when the fire reaches the area. The reduced fuel loading will reduce fire intensity. 

As of the morning update the fire has not yet reached Giant Sequoia Groves. Giant Sequoias are adapted for life with wildfire, but intense fire conditions that reach the crowns can damage and kill them. Last year at the Castle Fire experts estimate 10% of the Giant Sequoias in the region were damaged or killed. After an intense fire season covering major wildfires and drought throughout the state, I look forward to continuing to document this important story on one of America’s treasured national parks and groves of trees. Currently the complex is nearly 9,000 acres and 0% contained. A Type 1 Incident Management Team has taken over the fire as firefighting resources pour in to help in managing and suppressing the fire.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 16, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing, footwear and street.

node.text:
Photos and video by @davillasana / While Alexa Smith, a transgender woman from Honduras, wanted to migrate in 2019, her plans were stalled for more than one year after she broke her leg running from a man who attempted to assault her. In late 2020, however, threats from gang members for not being able to pay their extortions due to economic fallout from the pandemic, pushed her to finally flee Honduras. 

After a grueling journey through Mexico where she withstood cold temperatures sleeping on the streets at night and was physically assaulted by a group of men on la Bestia—the train that many migrants take to get to the U.S. border—she finally crossed into the U.S. earlier this year. “I'm ready to work hard to achieve my dreams," said Alexa. 

For an upcoming @natgeo story, writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) and I followed up with Alexa in Memphis, Tennessee, where she was living with her boyfriend and other Central American migrants. Stay tuned to hear more about what Alexa faced in her new home. 

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa

Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 16, 2021. May be an image of tree, nature and lake.

node.text: Photos by @macstonephoto / The land steward for The Nature Conservancy (@tnc_nc), Zach West, paddles through a stand of old growth bald cypress along the Black River. This river and its floodplain provides refuge for the oldest known bald cypress on the planet, which is more than 2,600 years old. @tnc_nc and its partners are working to conserve more habitat along this river corridor to protect these ancient trees. For more imagery of wetlands and swamps around the world follow @macstonephoto

Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, tree and nature.

node.text:
Photo by @andrea_frazzetta /  Ezra, 4 years old, walking with his schoolbag towards the kindergarten in the woods of Bergamo - "Come Tetto il Cielo” (The Sky as a Roof).
Inspired by the educational projects of northern Europe, the project involves fifteen children from 2 to 6 years old and their families. 
Following the principles of the Pedagogy of the Forest, and Experiential Learning, the children have the opportunity to carry out recreational activities in the woods, in direct contact with nature, during all seasons. 
This image is part of the series "Growing in the Woods”, a documentation project supported by @InsideNatGeo’s Emergency Fund for Journalists.
Bergamo was one of the hardest-hit cities in the world during the first wave of the pandemic in March 2020. 
The health emergency, which has overwhelmed Italy like few other countries in the world, has undoubtedly put the school system in serious difficulty. In particular, it has highlighted how this needs new, and safe, spaces, and a rethinking of the teaching method.
From January to June 2021, I documented 6 schools located in 6 different areas of the country, from North to South, in an attempt to tell the story of the diversity of the territories, the change of the seasons, and how these are intrinsically linked to the experiences of the children.
We live in a society that has the duty to find a different relationship with nature.
Through the photographic documentation of these stories, my goal is to spark reflection and debate, on a fundamental issue.
Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #Italy #outdooreducation #backtonature

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 15, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'SP'.

node.text: Photo by Michael Seeley @mseeley20 / A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launches with the Inspiration4 mission and a crew of four all-civilian astronauts as night settles over NASA's Kennedy Space Center Wednesday night.
